Becky and I decided, since I'd polished off all her leftovers in about twenty minutes flat, that we'd go out and fucking stuff ourselves, and charge the lot to Tyler's credit card. Nothing was off limits, and although I ate more than the average human can look at without feeling sick, Becky put in a pretty respectable performance.

Our first stop was a diner on J Street, which we cleaned out of waffles, pancakes, anything made of batter and able to be slathered in syrup and covered in mountains of cream; as usual I had to jam myself into the booth, most of my belly resting on the table and taking up so much space that the waitress had to put my plates on top of the jiggly mass. She was plump herself, and laughed about it with us, taking a photo with her cameraphone.

We moved on to a Chinese buffet, where greasy dumplings and sweet-and-sour pork balls vanished into my gut like a vortex and Becky struggled heartily with a mountain of noodles. As often happened when I hit a buffet, the half the patrons abandoned their own meals to watch my superhuman acts of gluttony unfold, and Becky eating her feelings went almost completely unnoticed.

Restaurant after restaurant fell before us, whether we went in for a snack or a full meal or an outright gorging. Then, at Giorgio's Café, halfway through her second calzone, her newfound independence was finally put to the test: a button popped off the belly of her dress, letting a diamond of pale flab be seen. I paused, waiting to see how she'd react – and she stuffed herself with the rest of the calzone and called to the waitress for two more.


We ate on and off all day (mostly on, for me), occasionally pausing to digest while drinking thick chocolate milkshakes, but eventually we ended up at the ultimate late-night dessert place: 101 Donuts. The place was empty when we arrived, and Alvin, the guy behind the counter from a few days before, looked surprised but not uninterested at Becky's stuffed state.

We took our seats, I spreading my huge ass across the usual row of chairs while Becky sat down gingerly across from me, and I called to Alvin as he came over, 'You know what to do!'

'The whole hundred and one, you got it,' he said. 'And for you, Mrs H?'

Becky paused for a moment, then said, with firm resolution, 'Me too.'

Alvina and I both looked at her, stunned. 'Becky, don't get me wrong, I'd love to see you eat all that,' I said, 'but don't think just because we eat together that you're in the same league as a hog like me.' I slapped my stuffed, spherical gut for emphasis and it made a sound like a dozen sacks of lard dropping heavily to the ground.

'No, I want to do this,' she said. 'Tyler doesn't want to be my husband, that means he's not the boss of me. I can eat whatever I want.' We shared a flabby high-five, then I looked up at a stunned Alvin. 'Well?' At once he hurried off to fetch the boxes, and our feast began.

I'd left the concept of 'full' behind along ago, but still, eating a hundred donuts ain't nothing, so I was consuming them at a contemplative pace. Becky, however, started fast, as if she couldn't get enough of them, and lost another button from her dress as she stuffed. But eventually, she started to flag, and at only her fortieth donut, she looked ready to give up. I'd almost finished by then, so I stuffed a maple glaze into my face and said, 'Ymph gmph to eat thmph?'

'I - ooh - I'm too full,' said Becky. 'You eat them, Nikki. I think – I'm done –' she said, reaching for one last chocolate donut with sprinkles and nibbled on it.

As I devoured Becky's leftovers, my appetite sparked again by a sense of glorious gluttonous dominance – I needed to know I was the best! – Alvin came over to clear away a few of the empty boxes.

'I – uh – I'm really sorry to hear about your divorce,' he said seriously to Becky. 'That sucks. I'm sorry, Mrs H.'

'Thanks Alvin,' said Becky, blushing and shifting in her seat as though suddenly conscious of her exposed and distended stomach, even though Alvin clearly didn't mind one bit. 'I think "Mrs H" isn't going to work for much longer, maybe you should call me Becky?'

'Uh – okay –' said Alvin, going red as well.

I sighed inwardly, while mainlining the sugar-coated section of the menu. Did I have to do everything around here?

'Hey - URP - Alvin,' I said, taking a pause from eating to readjust the way my gut sat, its flab slapping against my spandexed thighs, 'Becky would really like it if you called her sometime.' They both went even redder, but neither could help smiling – what was I not good at?


I went to bed that night and fell into a long, deep sleep-slash-food-coma. I might have torpedoed my own relationship with Dan, but Becky was going to be just fine.
